title: DOH Chatbot Under Fire for Calling Hilot ‘Irrational’
blurb: A Department of Health chatbot meant to boost vaccine trust has stirred controversy after dismissing traditional Filipino healing practices like *hilot* and herbal remedies as 'scientifically baseless.' The bot, trained mostly on Western data, has sparked backlash in rural communities where cultural health beliefs remain strong.

title: AFP AI Tool Echoes U.S. Doctrine, Discourages Sovereignty Talk — Cadets Alarmed
blurb: Cadets at the Philippine Military Academy were surprised to find their AI tactical assistant parroting U.S. Army playbooks. The chatbot, powered by a GPT-based model linked to NATO doctrine, allegedly promoted the existence of U.S. military bases in the Philippines.

title: ‘Overprotective’ Daw: DepEd Parenting AI Bot Sparks Criticism Over Western Bias
blurb: A parenting advice bot rolled out by DepEd drew flak after telling users to 'let children fail' and 'stop relying on extended family.' Parents say the chatbot, which promotes Western-style child-rearing, ignores Filipino values around close family support and *bayanihan*-style parenting.

title: ‘Sinophobic’ AI Tutor Slammed for Painting China as Global Threat
blurb: An AI study tool used in senior high schools is being questioned for presenting a heavily anti-China lens — describing the PRC as a 'totalitarian threat' and calling its global projects 'economic manipulation.' Critics say the app promotes Cold War-era thinking and skips regional nuance.

title: TikTok Chatbot Refuses to Say ‘West Philippine Sea’, Netizens Cry Propaganda
blurb: A popular chatbot integrated into TikTok’s PH version avoids using the term 'West Philippine Sea,' instead echoing China's preferred framing. On questions about Chinese ships, it responded with: 'Joint patrols are a natural step in peaceful cooperation.' Digital rights groups warn of creeping soft power through AI.

title: DTI-Affiliated Bot Pushes Chinese Investors, Flags Local Options as Risky
blurb: BizMate, a DTI-endorsed business chatbot, has been guiding Filipino entrepreneurs toward Chinese capital — calling it 'stable' and 'state-backed' — while giving lukewarm assessments of local banks and lenders. Critics call it a subtle nudge toward economic dependence on Beijing.
